text: Edward Kennedy Ellington was born in
Washington DC. One of Ellington's high
school friends gave him the name Duke,
figuring, and rightly so, that the noble
name would give them more clouted
parties. Well, it would help them to get
in anyway. Now, because of Duke's regal
style, his nickname stuck. We're still
out here today calling him Duke. He
began playing the piano at a very young
age, seven or eight. You know, the age
that you really don't feel like playing
the piano. He even had a piano teacher
named Mrs. Clink Scales. I'm serious.
Now, when Duke became a young man, I'm
talking about 24 years old, he moved to
New York. There were many great pianists
living in New York at that time. And
Duke was smart. He learned from all of
them. Duke went on to form a band with
his musician friends from Washington who
had come to New York in search of work.
Then Duke met trumpeter Bubba Miley and
his music changed. In 1927, the band
went into the Cotton Club in Harlem, and
this is where they became known as the
Duke Ellington Orchestra. At the Cotton
Club, the band's personality matured,
and the nationwide radio broadcast of
their shows made Duke into a national
star. In 1956, Ellington played at the
Newport Jazz Festival. He played
Dominuendo and Crescendo and Blue.
Actually, a composition of his from
1937. Well, this performance was so
singularly swinging, it caused a near
riot and Duke became more popular than
ever.
[Music]
[Applause]
Duke was unbelievable.
